section.name: Exporting data
section.p: When you set the Table Tag's export attribute to "true", a footer will appear below the table which will allow you to export the data being shown in various formats.

Displaytag includes few ready export view which allows you to export data in csv, excel o xml format. A simple Pdf export view is also available. The following table lists the predefined export options included in displaytag distribution.

tr.td: Export to excel - ascii format, tab separated

Sample Pdf export view. This is not enabled by default in the distribution but can be enabled setting export.pdf=true in displaytag.properties and including the required IText dependency (see displaytag dependencies ). Since you probably want to tweak the layout of your pdf output this is probably more useful as a base reference for creating your own Pdf export view.

section.name: Configuring export and export views
section.p:
The export.types parameter contains the list of registered export views. For each export type you can configure other parameters: see the
export. exportname .*
parameters in configuration .

You can enable/disable a specific export type using the
export. exportname .enabled
parameter.
If you don't want some column to show during export (or you want them to show only during export) you can use the column media attribute (see tag reference for more details).

ol.li:
Write your own exportView class. You need to implement the org.displaytag.export.TextExportView or org.displaytag.export.BinaryExportView interface. You can look at the sample binary PDF export view or to
the base text export view used by displaytag
.

Add a displaytag.properties file in your application classpath (if you already don't have one) and add the name of your export media along with the default ones to the export type parameter:
export.types=csv excel xml [mymedia]

Always in displaytag.properties , add the following properties:
export.[mymedia]=true
export.[mymedia].class=fully.qualified.class.name
export.[mymedia].label=Click here to try my export
# include header parameter is forwarded to your export view export.[mymedia].include_header=true
# if set, file is downloaded instead of opened in the browser window export.[mymedia].filename=

Try it. You should see a new link with the text you added to
export. mymedia .label
. Clicking on it will made you Export view to be called and you will se the result in your browser.

section.name: Text/Binary export views
section.p: Common displaytag export options (csv, xml and excel) output a simple text-based format. Other file format requires binary content, like the sample Pdf included with the distribution.

Exporting binary data from a jsp is a bit tricky, since jsps are only designed to output characters: as a starting point keep in mind that binary export is not assured to work on any application server , at least without the help of an external filter (see export filter ).

It may work without a filter if your application server allows jsps to call response.getOutputStream() , but this methods should not be used in jsps. Using an the export filter, expecially in buffered mode, could solve the problem, since the output stream is requested by the filter, outside the jsp.
